titleStmt.title: Letter from Samuel D. Williams to Edmond Van Eetvelde, May 4, 1898

bibl.title: Letter from Samuel D. Williams to Edmond Van Eetvelde

msIdentifier.repository: Ministère des Affaires étrangères, Brussels, Belgium

div1.p: 4th May 1898 His Excellency M. Van Etvelde Secretary of State Boma.
Sir:- As I understand your Government have no Consular Represent- ative resident at this Port I beg leave respectfully to make application as a Candidate for the Post.

I have resided in Newport for the last 27 years during the past 20 of which I have ocupied the position of Secretary to the Newport Chamber of Commerce Incorporated to which I was elected by the whole town in public Competition with many other Candidates.

I am not otherwise engaged in trade here either as a Shipowner or Shipbroker having no interest whatever in either of those direc- tions. I am thoroughly well acquainted with all the requirements of Consular work and my Status in the Port would enable me to fulfill the duties of the offices, if favoured with the appointment in a manner quite consistent with the dignity and independence requisite in such a post. As affording some idea of my thorough acquaintance with Commercial matters I herewith send by same post a copy of my last Annual Chamber of Commerce Report.

If my application is entertained I am in a position to submit references of the highest possible standing from all the leading Members of this Town and District Representative of the Nobility, Mayoralty, Magistracy, Trade, Commerce, and General Industry and which would shew that I enjoy the confidence of every section of this Community.
I shall be pleased to hear from you in response hereto at your convenience, Meantime, I remain Sir Your Excellency's Obedient Servant Samuel D. Williams
